La experiencia de la educación terciaria
            en Chile

theme: Administrative and civil service reform,Education for the knowledge economy

abstracts.cdata!:
This Result Profile talks about
            Chile's tertiary education experience. In 2005, the
            quality of tertiary education in Chile varied considerably,
            data was unreliable, and students from poor backgrounds
            faced an uphill battle to reach graduation. Internal
            inefficiencies plagued the tertiary education system, with
            first year dropout rates upwards of 20 percent in even the
            best universities, and overly long degree programs that
            dragged on more than planned. There were virtually no
            remedial classes to strengthen basic competencies. Finally,
            there was insufficient accountability and transparency in
            the use of direct public funding for tertiary education.
            With partial assistance from International Bank for
            Reconstruction and Development (IBRD) funding and expertise,
            Chile passed legislation on quality assurance and student
            financial aid, set up a tertiary education information
            system, increased the availability of advanced human capital
            and research capacity, and piloted four performance
            agreements with universities. The success of these
            agreements provided proof-of-concept for results-based
            financing. Tertiary education enrollment in Chile rose by 51
            percent between 2005 and 2010, from 646,000 to 973,000
            students. Chile was able to improve both quality and equity
            of education despite this massive expansion.
